ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the evolutionary history and anatomy of birds, with a particular focus on feathers and development.
I learned SO MUCH about birds
I learned a ton about birds. It was a fantastic class. We learned about so many different facets about birds.

Overview of bird diversity, evolution, morphology, feather structure & development, migration, flight, sexual displays, and much much more. You will learn a LOT about birds and become very excited about it!
This class was a really fun survey into ornithology phylogeny, bird behavior and biology.
I learned so much about birds. Bird evolution, physiology, behavior, reproduction, migration, feeding, thermoregulation, everything.
I learned about birds.
I learned a great deal about birds and it was great.
Learned about birds, as well as how to track a specific question through the history of scientific writing.
I learned a lot about the physiology and behavior of birds.
I learned about the evolution and biology of birds

We go into considerable depth into the evolution and physiology of the avian phenotype, focusing on flight, digestion, navigation, sight etc. We constantly used concepts from other disciplines in order to make sense of the systems in question. I came into the class expecting knowledge of birds but left the class with a newfound appreciation for the utility of physics, development, and even economics in the study of evolutionary biology.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class is an in depth look at many aspects of birds as a group.

Strengths: really great, informative, cohesive, well thought out lectures. Also not much work outside of class. 
Weaknesses: don't even try to ask a question, you will get 10 mins of unrelated tangent and no answer

Birdwatching with Prum was fun! It's tough to evaluate this course imagined as a non-pandemic course, I just know that it wasn't the perfect class for the recorded lecture format. I think the in-person excitement is probably the most important thing about this course in a typical year.
This was a fantastic class. No comments.

Strengths: AWESOME PROFESSOR. Rick Prum is a legend within the bird community who has made a few seminal discoveries in ornithology which you get to learn about throughout the semester. Enjoyable class with interesting lectures. Appropriate workload, the right amount to keep you excited about the material. Good overview of a lot of different topics. Weaknesses: 9 am on MWF.
I thought this class was really strong, no suggestions.

The course was well-structured, and you will learn a lot of interesting things! Professor Prum is amazing and is very passionate, and I found the course very engaging. There is a lot of content, but it's well worth it.
Great course, weakened significantly by the online format. Professor Prum is fantastic, and the structure of the course is reasonable.

Strengths: This course was fascinating! Dr. Prum is a great lecturer who makes the material very interesting with lots of stories and anecdotes. The workload was reasonable, and made engaging for the most part. 

Weaknesses: One thing is that the work felt really biased towards the end of the semester, especially when combined with the associated lab. Having two papers due within a few days of each other, as well as the class final very early in finals period was a lot to deal with at the same time as every other class having final papers due. This was obviously an unconventional year though, and the lab papers were a new type of assignment so some difficulties were to be expected.

The term paper also felt a bit sudden. I think it would have been nice to dedicate some time to discussing it earlier on. 

I'm not sure that I would exactly call it a weakness, but the lectures are organized in a really conversationally-flowing way that naturally came around to stories and whatnot. This made them engaging to listen to and is preferable to dry bullet point lists. But at times it did make it challenging to know that the notes I took were adequate.
The material was really interesting, and the professor was very enthusiastic and engaging. I also really liked the in-person birding events and would have liked more of those.

Considering how many topics we covered, the class was very well-organized. Each new unit built upon the last resulting in a comprehensive summary of the biology of modern birds. While there were a few challenging concepts to grapple with, Dr. Prum had no shortage of analogies and helpful graphics in his powerpoints to ease any confusion. The term paper was valuable in that it encouraged us to delve deeper into topics we found interesting, but, especially towards the start of the project, I felt as though I did not exactly know what was expected of me. Some more direction, especially for those who have never written a review paper, would be useful. While it is only a weakness if students are not engaged with the content, the lack of assignments for the first half of the semester might make students who don't review the material to slip behind before the first exam.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lecture seemed to translate well to Zoom.
I thought this class translated really well to zoom. It was great to be able to go back to the lectures to study or to watch later if you didn't make it to the 9:25 live class.
This class did great during covid, no recommendations

I appreciated access to recorded lectures, and the class was very engaging despite the realities of the Zoom environment. Tests were changed to an open-book format, which also alleviated some of the pressure.
The Zoom lectures were enjoyable and the exams were low stress. It would have been nice to have more opportunities to interact with other students in the class

I did not see any aspect of the class decline as a result of the online format. It seems like the class typically revolved around powerpoint slides, which allowed for a seamless transition into an online format. Dr. Prum's enthusiastic commentary was suitable to maintain student engagement even through an online format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to any student with some prior preparation in evolution and a general interest in the subject.
Yes, absolutely. It's so interesting and (at least this year) a gut.

I would certainly recommend this lecture. Even as someone who is not particularly involved in the sciences, I very much enjoyed the class. I imagine, of course, that it would have been an even better experience. under the conditions of in-person learning.
Yes. Prum is an expert in his field and an entertaining lecturer.
Absolutely. This course was amazing. I loved every class.
ABSOLUTELY. If you are even remotely interested in birds, TAKE THIS CLASS. It is easily the best class I have taken at Yale.
Absolutely! This class is so fun and you learn a ton! I had a great time
If you have any interest in birds whatsoever, whether in the lab or for birdwatching, you must take this course. It is wonderful in so many ways.
Yes, but not as a gut. Only take this if you are ready for the commitment.

Yes! You will learn a lot about birds and Professor Prum is so enthusiastic about the subject! This course was a great experience. There is a lot of content, but tests were changed to be open-book, so it wasn't much of an issue for the COVID edition of the class - otherwise, prepare for memorization and the need to take notes very carefully. That being said, the content is fascinating and bird-related facts were definitely a non-negligible component of my conversations with my friends this semester!!! Highly recommend.

I would highly recommend this course to any student. I took it as a non-science major and it was a lot of fun immersing myself in the field. Professor Prum is the selling point of the coursehe's passionate, interesting, and a really sweet guy. The semi-regular birdwatching expeditions were also really cool, and gave the class a more practical dimension
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in birds or looking for a fun science credit!

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who has even a vague interest of birds. The class covers so many aspects of their biology that there is bound to be at least a few topics that will captivate just about anyone. I would also strongly suggest to take the lab along with the class, since it attached the general information we learned in class to specific examples across the lineage. But be warned that you won't get your first grade until the midterm and the last few weeks can get very hectic with the final and term paper to take care of. That being said START THE TERM PAPER EARLY and you'll be perfectly fine.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No other modes.
live lectures were recorded
Mix of live virtual lectures and recorded virtual lectures
Live lectures were recorded and could be watched back.
Live virtual lecture with recorded lectures available. My attendance was split about 75/25
